questions.question: Which of the following best describes the divide and conquer technique?

answers.a: Solving a problem by trying all possible solutions
answers.b: Dividing a problem into smaller sub-problems, solving them, and combining the results
answers.c: Solving a problem iteratively using loops
answers.d: Sorting elements by comparing adjacent values

explanations.a: This describes brute-force techniques, not divide and conquer.
explanations.b: Divide and conquer works by breaking a problem into smaller parts, solving them recursively, and combining results.
explanations.c: Iterative approaches use loops rather than recursion.
explanations.d: This describes bubble sort, not the divide and conquer paradigm.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for using sorting algorithms in computer science?

answers.c: To organize data for efficient searching and processing

explanations.a: Sorting may increase memory usage depending on the algorithm.
explanations.b: Sorting does not directly improve security.
explanations.c: Sorted data allows faster searching and easier data processing.
explanations.d: Program length is unrelated to sorting.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Merge Sort in the worst case?

explanations.a: Merge Sort always processes all elements at each level.
explanations.b: Merge Sort divides the array log n times and merges n elements at each level.
explanations.c: Quadratic time is typical of simple sorts like bubble sort.
explanations.d: Logarithmic time alone is insufficient to process all elements.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Merge Sort is TRUE?

answers.a: It is an in-place sorting algorithm
answers.b: Its performance depends on input order
answers.c: It uses extra memory for merging
answers.d: It has a worst-case time complexity of O(n²)

explanations.b: Merge Sort performance is independent of input order.
explanations.c: Extra memory is used to merge subarrays.
explanations.d: Its worst-case time complexity is O(n log n).

questions.question: In Quick Sort, what is the role of the pivot element?

answers.a: It stores the final sorted array
answers.b: It divides the array into two subarrays based on comparison
answers.c: It determines the size of the input array
answers.d: It is always the smallest element

explanations.a: The pivot does not store the sorted array.
explanations.b: The pivot partitions the array into elements smaller and larger than itself.
explanations.c: Array size is independent of the pivot.
explanations.d: The pivot can be any element depending on selection strategy.
